{"abstract": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, increased its net income 26 percent, to $1.9 billion, compared with a year ago.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/29/business/media/comcast-profits-up-sharply-along-with-tv-subscribers.html", "snippet": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, increased its net income 26 percent, to $1.9 billion, compared with a year ago.", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast, the nation\u2019s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, on Tuesday reported a sharp increase in profit for the fourth quarter of 2013, helped by an increase in television subscribers after six years of decline.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "6", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Comcast Profits Up Sharply, Along With TV Subscribers", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Comcast Profits Up Sharply, Along With TV Subscribers", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Cable Television", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-01-29T02:14:15+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Ravi Somaiya", "person": [{"firstname": "Ravi", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Somaiya", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/fecf90c6-7138-5f97-a5a5-34b4cb9f4181", "word_count": 443, "uri": "nyt://article/fecf90c6-7138-5f97-a5a5-34b4cb9f4181"}

{"abstract": "The deal for Time Warner Cable appears set to generate a return on investment below Comcast\u2019s cost of capital, which is not surprising given the medieval governance the Roberts family uses to oversee its fiefdom, write Rob Cox and Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/02/13/caught-beneath-the-wheels-of-the-comcast-juggernaut/", "snippet": "The deal for Time Warner Cable appears set to generate a return on investment below Comcast\u2019s cost of capital, which is not surprising given the medieval governance the Roberts family uses to oversee its fiefdom, write Rob Cox and Jeffrey Goldfarb...", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast\u2019s deal machine has spit out a value destroyer. Digesting Time Warner Cable is ambitious even for a serial acquirer like Comcast\u2019s chief executive, Brian Roberts. As with some of his many previous purchases, it looks set to generate a return on investment below Comcast\u2019s cost of capital. That\u2019s crummy but not criminal. {"abstract": "With the Time Warner Cable deal, Comcast would not only lock up 30 percent of the cable market, but pricing leverage in all directions \u2014 with customers, networks and over-the-web providers like Netflix.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/17/business/media/stealthily-comcast-fortifies-its-arsenal.html", "snippet": "With the Time Warner Cable deal, Comcast would not only lock up 30 percent of the cable market, but pricing leverage in all directions \u2014 with customers, networks and over-the-web providers like Netflix.", "lead_paragraph": "Big media companies are generally warships, bristling with firepower and declaring their might long before they attack. But Comcast, which is headed toward being one of the biggest of them all, is much more like a submarine, silently running beneath the waves and making its presence known only when it is too late for its targets. {"abstract": "Reed Hastings said that once Netflix agreed to pay Comcast for a better connection, Netflix customers no longer experienced delays streaming video.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/21/business/media/netflix-chief-alters-view-on-net-deal.html", "snippet": "Reed Hastings said that once Netflix agreed to pay Comcast for a better connection, Netflix customers no longer experienced delays streaming video.", "lead_paragraph": "Less than a month after Netflix insisted that its deal to pay Comcast to get a more direct connection to the company\u2019s Internet pipes had nothing to do with net neutrality, Netflix\u2019s chief executive, Reed Hastings, said Thursday that, well, yes it did.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Netflix Chief Alters View on Net Neutrality", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Netflix Chief Alters View on Net Deal", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "persons", "value": "Wyatt, Edward", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Net Neutrality", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Netflix Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Comcast Corporation", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Hastings, Reed", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-03-21T00:25:00+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By Edward Wyatt", "person": [{"firstname": "Edward", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Wyatt", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/f709cdee-5f79-5887-be31-2fff9335c1a8", "word_count": 392, "uri": "nyt://article/f709cdee-5f79-5887-be31-2fff9335c1a8"}

{"abstract": "Comcast is locked into its deal with Time Warner Cable unless it gets a timely assist from the Federal Communications Commission, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/13/net-neutrality-review-could-give-comcast-an-out-in-the-time-warner-cable-deal/", "snippet": "Comcast is locked into its deal with Time Warner Cable unless it gets a timely assist from the Federal Communications Commission, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column.", "lead_paragraph": "Comcast\u2019s acquisition of Time Warner Cable has already drawn many heated detractors to urge the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal. Now, it has been hit been hit yet again by President Obama\u2019s endorsement of net neutrality. Comcast may have buyer\u2019s remorse, but it may find that ironically, the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block this deal. M.&A. makes strange bedfellows indeed. {"abstract": "Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett\u2019s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/14/morning-agenda-net-neutralitys-effect-on-comcast/", "snippet": "Net neutrality could give Comcast a way out of its Time Warner Cable acquisition. | Warren E. Buffett\u2019s deal for Duracell satisfies a number of his deal-making preferences. | Virgin America to begin trading. | Goldman seeks to lure tech talent.", "lead_paragraph": "NET NEUTRALITY COULD AFFECT COMCAST\u2019S DEAL | Comcast\u2019s $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable may have seemed like a good idea earlier this year. But now that President Obama has endorsed net neutrality, Comcast might have buyer\u2019s remorse, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Given how much detractors have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal, Comcast may now find, ironically, that the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block the transaction. \u201cThis F.C.C. battle all comes down to whether bigger in and of itself is a problem, and President Obama\u2019s statements only add to the troubles for this deal,\u201d Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Net Neutrality\u2019s Effect on Comcast", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-11-14T12:32:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e21da142-b56b-55d2-9b67-9634e6dc1679", "word_count": 2282, "uri": "nyt://article/e21da142-b56b-55d2-9b67-9634e6dc1679"}

{"abstract": "Comcast\u2019s record of compliance is now in the spotlight as regulators, and senators like Al Franken, scrutinize its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/22/business/media/6-senators-urge-rejection-of-comcast-time-warner-cable-deal.html", "snippet": "Comcast\u2019s record of compliance is now in the spotlight as regulators, and senators like Al Franken, scrutinize its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable.", "lead_paragraph": "In July 2013, executives from the three companies that co-owned Hulu \u2014 Comcast, 21st Century Fox and Walt Disney \u2014 had a conversation about their joint venture. Hulu, the video streaming service, had been on the auction block, and lucrative bids had come in from two Comcast rivals, AT&T and the satellite operator DirecTV, among other potential buyers.", {"abstract": "Although Netflix\u2019s strategy is not without a fair amount of risk, it just keeps working \u2014 and the company\u2019s prospects are steadily brightening.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/14/technology/why-media-titans-need-to-worry-about-netflix.html", "snippet": "Although Netflix\u2019s strategy is not without a fair amount of risk, it just keeps working \u2014 and the company\u2019s prospects are steadily brightening.", "lead_paragraph": "Imagine you run a global media conglomerate. Roberts, of Comcast, or perhaps you\u2019re slightly lower down on the ladder of behemoths \u2014 the boss of Twenty-First Century Fox or Time Warner, perhaps. {"abstract": "Billboards, long used by big brands to promote their products, and more recently by tech companies, are flourishing compared with other traditional media.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/05/business/media/look-up-in-the-digital-age-billboards-are-far-from-dead.html", "snippet": "Billboards, long used by big brands to promote their products, and more recently by tech companies, are flourishing compared with other traditional media.", "lead_paragraph": "When Axl Rose ended a 23-year feud with his former Guns N\u2019 Roses bandmates, Duff McKagan and Slash, and agreed to reunite with them onstage in 2016, the band unveiled its North American tour in an unusual way.
